item.title: Our Experience at the International Coffee Festival, Bengaluru
item.description: We attended the IICF this year and this is the reason we were over-caffeinated.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
Vikra and I attended the India International Coffee Festival (IICF) in Bangalore last week. It was a 3-day event and we went for the last two days.

We left with shaky hands, racing hearts, and way too many ideas.

Turns out, saying "yes" to every sample at a coffee festival has consequences. But I'd do it again. Every single sip of it.

The championships were unreal

If you've never watched a barista championship live, it's hard to explain how intense it gets. These aren't people casually making lattes. They're performing under a clock, in front of judges, with techniques they've rehearsed for months.

The stories they come up with are the best part.

The brewing championship was my favourite. Watching someone dial in a recipe with that level of precision, adjusting grind size by microns, timing pours to the second. It makes you realise how much depth there is to a "simple" cup of coffee.

And then there were the cocktail rounds.

One recipe I immediately wrote down: an Irish coffee made with a pour over. The barista brewed a clean pour over, added Jameson whiskey, and floated sweet cream on top. Not your typical Irish coffee with a French press or drip. A pour over. I'm definitely trying this at home. Wish me luck. Wish my kitchen luck.

At some point I also took over brewing at the Project Kaapi stall. They're a roaster from Hyderabad, like us. It was fun being on the other side, making pour overs for people walking by.

Osmotic flow and the Cafec founder

This was the highlight I didn't expect.

The founder of Cafec gave a session on osmotic flow. He explained the science behind how water moves through coffee grounds and why it matters for extraction. He also explained why you don't need to pre-wet Cafec's Abaca filters, which goes against what most of us have been taught.

Here's what made it special. He spoke entirely in Japanese. There was a translator for us, but honestly, you didn't always need one. The way he talked about his work, the gestures, the energy, the pride. It transcended language.

There's something beautiful about watching someone explain their life's work with that kind of passion. You could tell this wasn't a sales pitch. This was a person who genuinely loves the science of brewing and has spent decades thinking about how water and paper and coffee interact.

I walked out of that session looking at the Cafec dripper very differently.

We met some of you

We sent out an email the day before saying we'll be at the festival. A couple of you showed up and said hi. It was nice to put faces to the people reading these emails.

Between meeting readers and even reading all the replies we get, it makes the whole thing feel real. Thanks for coming out.

The festival hangover

I don't mean alcohol, though those championship cocktail recipes are tempting.

I mean the kind where your brain is buzzing with too many ideas. New brewing methods to try, recipes to recreate, people to follow up with, and a newfound respect for filter paper science.

Also, my resting heart rate was noticeably higher for about two days after. Worth it.

If there is anything you would like to know more, let me know. And if have been there, I'd love to hear about your experience.

That’s all I have. Have a caffeinated weekend.

See you.

Keep on brewing!

item.title: Cappuccino - The Drink That Wears a Hood
item.description: The coffee drink which is, surprisingly, not from Italy.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I was at a cafe the other day, staring at the menu and a friend asked me, "what's actually the difference between cappuccino, latte and flat white?"

I opened my mouth. Paused. And realized I didn't have a clean answer.

So I went down the rabbit hole. And it turns out, the cappuccino has one of the most interesting origin stories in the coffee world.

A Drink Named After Monks

The word "cappuccino" literally means "little hood" in Italian. It comes from the Capuchin monks: a Catholic order known for their simple brown hooded robes. When you pour milk into espresso and that rich brown color appears, it looks exactly like the color of those robes.

But the cappuccino we know today didn't start in Italy.

It started as the Kapuziner in 1700s Vienna which is coffee mixed with cream and sugar, sometimes spices. A very different drink.

Kapuziner from Vienna

It wasn't until espresso machines took over Italy post-WW2 that the modern cappuccino was born. Espresso pulled through pressure, topped with steamed milk and a thick cap of foam.

Fun fact - in Italy, it became a strictly morning drink. Order a cappuccino after 11am there, and you've just outed yourself as a tourist.

What Actually Goes Into One

The classic cappuccino follows a simple ratio: 1/3 espresso, 1/3 steamed milk, 1/3 microfoam.

That's it. But the magic is in the foam.

Surprised there is no art? More on it below.

A good cappuccino has thick, velvety foam that holds its shape, not the bubbly, airy kind you get from a French press frother. The milk is steamed to around 60-65°C, which is the sweet spot where lactose breaks down and the milk tastes naturally sweet.

It's a drink about texture as much as taste. That pillowy foam layer on top, the warm milk underneath, and a strong espresso punch cutting through it all.

So How Is It Different From a Latte or Flat White?

This is the question that started this whole post. Here's the simplest way to see it:

Drink

Espresso

Steamed Milk

Foam

Cappuccino

1/3

1/3

1/3 (thick)

Latte

1/6

4/6

1/6 (thin)

Flat White

1/3

2/3

micro-thin layer

Cappuccino has the strongest coffee flavor of the three. You taste the espresso through the foam.

Latte is the milkiest where coffee takes a backseat. It's smooth, gentle, and the go-to order for people who want coffee-flavored milk. No shade if you prefer this.

Flat White sits in between. It's espresso-forward like a cappuccino but silky smooth like a latte which no foam cap sitting on top. Just a thin microfoam layer blended into the milk.

But What About the Art?

Latte art was born on, you guessed it, lattes. Thinner foam gives you a flat canvas, making it easy to pour hearts and rosettas. With traditional cappuccinos, you'd just get a white dome of foam. No canvas, no art.

But third-wave cafes (not to be confused with Third Wave Coffee) changed the game. Baristas started texturing cappuccino foam thinner, closer to flat white consistency, so they could pour art on top. Walk into any specialty cafe today and your cappuccino probably has a rosetta on it.

There's a tradeoff though. A cappuccino with latte art has less foam than a traditional one. Purists will tell you that's basically just a small latte. They're not entirely wrong. But honestly, if it looks beautiful and tastes great , does the label really matter?

So, are you a cappuccino person, a latte person, or a flat white person?

That’s all I have. Have a caffeinated weekend.

item.title: SCA Sensory Skills Certification: What I Learned and Unlearned
item.description: I went to the coffee school and got certified. Here's what the training was like, and whether it's worth it for home brewers.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
After 4+ years of brewing speciality coffee at home, reading about it, writing about it — I finally got officially certified. SCA Sensory Skills, Foundation and Intermediate. Here's what that was like.

Am I tasting just water?

Why get certified?

You can learn a lot on your own. YouTube, blogs, trial and error — I've done all of that. But there was always this itch. Am I tasting this right? Is my understanding of acidity actually correct? After years of pushing it off, I finally committed.

SCA stands for the Speciality Coffee Association — the global body behind coffee standards, grading, and education. Their Sensory Skills module specifically teaches you how to evaluate coffee. Not brew it. Evaluate it. It's about tasting with intention.

The training: SCAI, Bangalore

I trained at the Speciality Coffee Association of India (SCAI) in Bangalore. 4-day course — 2 days for Foundation, 2 days for Intermediate. I initially signed up only for the Foundation. But by the end of day two, I knew I had to continue. The Foundation was going so well that skipping the Intermediate felt like leaving mid-conversation.

Mornings were theory. Afternoons were all cupping — tables full of cups, lots of slurping, and discussions about what everyone was tasting. The group was a mix of roasters, café owners, and enthusiasts like me.

What I unlearned

This was the best part. Honestly, the unlearning was more valuable than the learning.

Acidity ≠ sour. I had a skewed understanding of acidity in coffee. For years, I associated high acidity with something unpleasant — something to avoid. Turns out, acidity is brightness. Liveliness. It's a quality attribute. When done right, it's what makes a cup interesting. I was rating coffees down for the very thing that made them good.

Flavour notes and taste qualities are independent. This one was a revelation. If a coffee bag says "orange", or you identify it as a flavour note, it doesn't mean the coffee should be highly acidic. Flavour descriptors and qualities like acidity, sweetness, body — they exist on independent axes. You can have an orange-noted coffee that's low in acidity. I'd been conflating the two for years.

What makes coffee "good" isn't randomness. I thought I had a decent sense for quality. Well, I was partially right. The SCA framework gives you a structured way to score coffee across specific attributes — fragrance, acidity, body, balance, aftertaste, and more. It recalibrated my palate. What I used to call "nice" now has specific words and scores attached to it.

Realizing you've been confidently wrong about some things is really humbling. Four years of brewing doesn't make you immune to bad assumptions.

What I learned

One of the first activities in the Foundation was tasting the basic tastes — sweet, sour, bitter, salt, and umami — in water. Then we mapped where on our tongues we felt each taste. Turns out, it can be slightly different for each person.

And yes, umami is found in coffee. It's hard to describe — it's that feeling of enjoying something and also not being fully satiated. If you've had Maggi or anything with MSG, you know the taste. Finding it in coffee was unexpected.

Oh boy, I took a lot of notes.

The cupping protocol changed how I evaluate new coffee bags at home. There's a specific ratio, water temperature, steep time, and a method for breaking the crust. It's simple once you learn it, but it gives you a much cleaner read on a coffee than just brewing it your usual way.

The biggest shift was learning to isolate specific taste attributes instead of going with a general "this is nice". You learn to separate acidity from sweetness from body, score each independently, and build a more complete picture.

And triangulation tests — where you identify the odd cup out from three — are harder than you'd think. I tried this experiment with my coffee-drinking friends after the course, and they loved it. Great party trick if your friends are into coffee.

Was it worth it?

Passed both levels and it is genuinely satisfying.

Would I recommend it to a home brewer? Yes — especially if you've been at it for a while and feel like you've plateaued. It won't make your coffee taste better. But it'll make you taste better.

If you're even slightly curious, go for it. The unlearning alone is worth the experience.

That’s all I have. Have a caffeinated weekend.

See you.

item.title: Pour Over Extraction
item.description: How to extract for different notes, brightness, body, and acidity
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
"How do I get the blueberry out of this Ethiopian?"

I see this question pop up constantly. Someone buys a bag with tasting notes promising blueberry, jasmine, and citrus. They brew it. They taste... coffee. Maybe some sourness. Maybe some bitterness. But blueberry? Where is it hiding?

Here's the uncomfortable truth: you might never taste exactly what the roaster tasted. And that's okay. But there are things you can do to get closer.

Why Tasting Notes Are Slippery

Before we dive into extraction, let's set expectations.

Those tasting notes on the bag were written by a cupper who tasted the coffee under specific conditions – usually as a cupping, not a pour over. They might have used different water, different equipment, and they've calibrated their palate over thousands of cups.

You're not wrong if you taste something different. You're just not calibrated to their team.

That said, the flavours are real. They exist in the bean. The question is how to coax them out.

The Extraction EQ

Think of extraction like a three-band equalizer.

High notes – acids, brightness, tartness. These extract first and fastest, even at lower temperatures. The sharp citrus zing, the tangy berry notes.

Mid notes – sweetness, fruit character, floral aromatics. This is where the "blueberry" and "jasmine" live. The compounds that make each coffee distinct.

Low notes – body, bitterness, roasty depth. These extract last and need more persuasion.

A balanced cup has all three in harmony. But if you're chasing a specific note, you need to understand which band it lives in and how to bring it forward.

Practical Adjustments

Here's where it gets actionable.

For More Fruit and Floral Notes (Mid-Range)

These are the hardest to extract consistently. They need enough extraction to come out, but not so much that they get buried by bitterness.

Extend your bloom. Instead of the standard 30-45 seconds, try 60-90 seconds. Longer bloom times push the mid notes forward. I've had success with 2-minute blooms on stubborn light roasts using a coarser grind.

Increase agitation during bloom. Give it a good stir, or swirl the brewer. This helps saturate all grounds evenly and pulls more of those delicate aromatics.

Use hotter water. For light roasts, push to 96°C or even just off boil. Those dense beans need heat to open up. One experiment found that 211°F (99°C) throughout the brew produced the fruitiest results compared to dropping temperature mid-brew.

Try a higher ratio. 1:16.5 or 1:17 can increase fruit and acidity perception. You're extracting more from the same amount of coffee.

For More Brightness and Acidity (High Notes)

If you want that citrus zing or berry tartness to pop:

Coarser grind, tighter ratio. A 1:14 or 1:15 ratio with a coarser grind produces a sweet cup with pronounced acidity and lighter body.

Faster brew time. Aim for 2:30-2:45 total. Less contact time means more acids, less bitterness.

Let it cool. Seriously. Many fruit notes become more apparent as the coffee drops to 60-70°C. Take your time sipping.

For More Sweetness and Body (Balancing the Low End)

Sometimes the fruit notes are there but feel thin or disconnected:

Finer grind, slower extraction. More contact time brings out sugar browning flavours and body.

Multiple pours with gentle agitation. This builds body without over-extracting.

Rest your beans longer. Fresh-off-roast coffee can taste one-dimensional. Day 7-12 often shows the best balance for light roasts.

The Freshness Factor

This one surprised me when I first learned it.

Floral and fruity notes are volatile – they're the first to fade as beans age. Some cuppers report peak florals straight out of the roaster, fading by day 3-4. Others find day 5-12 is the sweet spot.

There's no universal answer here. But if you bought beans specifically for their fruity notes and they taste flat, check the roast date. If it's been 3+ weeks, the blueberry might have already left the building.

What If You Still Can't Taste It?

A few honest possibilities.

The beans might just not be that fruity. Tasting notes vary lot to lot. A roaster might have cupped a different batch than what ended up in your bag.

Your palate needs calibration. While eating a blueberry, sense how it tastes. Your brain will start making connections.

Your water might be off. TDS between 40-140 ppm with good mineral balance makes a huge difference. Hard water or distilled water both flatten flavour.

Your grinder produces too many fines. Excessive fines cause uneven extraction, muddying the cup. Sifting with a tea strainer can help if you suspect this.

The honest answer to "how do I get blueberry from this Ethiopian" is: maybe you will, maybe you won't. But pushing your extraction with higher temps, longer blooms, and proper agitation gives you the best shot.

And sometimes the coffee just tastes like really good coffee. That's enough too.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, what tasting note have you been chasing? Have you managed to nail it, or is it still elusive?

See you and have a caffeinated weekend.

item.title: Pour Over Coffee Setup - 2026 Buying Guide
item.description: These are all you need to brew killer pour over coffee for years to come by.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
Three friends have asked me this month – "what do I need to start making pour over at home?" After telling each one the same things, I'm writing it down so it helps more people.

I have been making pour overs since 4 years, and picked up a lot of drippers over these years.

The internet will overwhelm you with options. Fancy kettles, expensive grinders, ceramic drippers in seventeen colours. You don't need all of that. Here's the setup I'd recommend if I were starting fresh today. Not just passable coffee, but a good coffee.

Around ₹15,000, you will build a coffee setup that will serve you for years to come by.

The Essentials

The Dripper – Plastic Hario V60 (~₹500)

No need to go fancy here. The plastic V60 has been my daily driver for over 4 years now. Surprisingly, plastic retains heat better than ceramic. If you make more coffee, get the 02 size – it handles 1-2 cups comfortably.

The Grinder – 1zpresso Q Air (~₹6,000)

Fresh ground coffee is non-negotiable. Pre-ground loses flavour faster than you'd think. And grinder is the costliest part of any coffee setup. This grinder hits the sweet spot between price and grind consistency. Hand grinding takes a minute and honestly, I find it meditative. This grinder will serve you for years.

I own the Timemore C2 which is not easy to find now, and for a small price difference I find 1zpresso Q Air worth it.

The Scale – Hoffen Digital Scale (~₹1200)

Eyeballing things will only take you so far. Coffee brewing is basically chemistry, and chemistry needs precision. Get one that measures in grams and has a built-in timer. Once you start weighing your coffee and water, you'll notice how much more consistent your cups become.

The Kettle – Cipher Gooseneck Kettle (₹7000)

A gooseneck gives you precise pour control – this matters more than you'd expect. Regular kettles dump water too fast and unevenly. The controlled flow helps with even extraction. If you can get one with temperature control, even better. Light roasts need hotter water, darks need cooler.

I started using Cipher Kettle 2 months ago after a renowned coffee roaster recommended. I love it.

(Optional) The Server – Timemore Coffee Server (~₹1700)

The main advantage of this is that we can swirl it around, mix well, and aerate it before pouring it into a cup. Coffee extracts unevenly and it's good to mix it well before drinking. See the post on Sour vs Bitter for more info.

Without this, you can just put the dripper on any cup and maybe mix it with a spoon without drinking.

All this amounts to ₹16,400, including the Server

Upgrade Path

When you're ready to level up, the grinder is where your money makes the biggest difference.

The 1Zpresso JX or JX-Pro offers finer adjustment and works well if you want to try espresso later. If the budget allows, the Commandante C40 is what many enthusiasts swear by.

After the grinder, Switch would have the most ROI.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, what will you buy or which one will you upgrade?

That’s all I have. Have a caffeinated weekend.

item.title: Making Cold Brew Tonic
item.description: Dissecting a famous coffee drink and why it should not be paired with espresso.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I was at a cafe recently and noticed "Cold Brew Tonic" on their menu. Coffee and tonic? Sounded odd. But I ordered it anyway.

It was surprisingly good. Refreshing, slightly bitter, with a nice fizz. I had to figure out how to make this at home.

No equipment? No problem.

The cold brew part is easy. You don't need any fancy gear.

Take a mason jar or any container you have. Add coarsely ground coffee – think french press coarse. The ratio I use is 1:8, so about 30g of coffee to 240g of water. Stir it once to make sure all the grounds are wet.

Cover it and put it in the fridge. Wait 18-24 hours. That's the hardest part, waiting.

Strain it through a cloth, a paper filter, or even a fine sieve. What you get is a cold brew concentrate. Strong, smooth, and ready to be mixed.

A little history on tonic

Tonic water has an interesting backstory.

The bitter flavour comes from quinine, extracted from the bark of the cinchona tree in South America. British soldiers in India used to take quinine to prevent malaria (it tastes horrible).

So they mixed it with sugar and carbonated water to make it drinkable. That's how "tonic" water was born. Eventually, someone added gin to it and the rest is history.

Today's tonic has way less quinine – just enough for that distinctive bitter-sweet taste. Good ones like Fever-Tree or Sepoy & Co have botanical notes that work beautifully with coffee.

Why cold brew works better than espresso

You might wonder – why not just use espresso?

Espresso is hot. When it hits cold tonic and ice, the temperature shock melts everything fast.

Cold brew, on the other hand, is already cold. No temperature clash.

There's also the taste. Cold brew is naturally smoother, less acidic, and slightly sweet. Espresso can be both sour and bitter – when diluted with tonic, that unevenness becomes more apparent. Cold brew's mellow character complements tonic's bitterness instead of fighting it.

The recipe

Fill a glass with ice. Pour about 120ml of chilled tonic water. Slowly add 30-40ml of cold brew concentrate over the ice – you'll see it create a nice layered effect.

Add a squeeze of lime if you like. Stir and drink.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, have you tried mixing cold brew with anything unusual? I'm curious to know.

item.title: Sour vs Bitter notes: How to identify them
item.description: Learn to identify sour vs bitter notes in your coffee with a simple experiment, tips and comparisons to identify, and quick fixes.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I have been brewing coffee for 5+ years, and I still sometimes stare at my cup, wondering, “Is this sour or is this bitter?”

Turns out, most of us struggle with this. We know something is off, but we can't quite pinpoint what. And without knowing which one it is, fixing it becomes a guessing game.

Today, let's break this down. And I have an experiment for you that will make this crystal clear.

What Gets Extracted When

Coffee extraction happens in phases. When hot water hits your grounds, it doesn't pull everything out at once.

First come the acids – citric, malic acids. Bright, sharp, tangy notes that dissolve quickly.

Then comes the sweetness – sugars and caramelized compounds. The balanced zone we're chasing.

Last come the bitter compounds – tannins and heavier molecules. They add body, but too much makes the cup harsh.

When all three are balanced, you get a beautiful cup. When one dominates, things go wrong.

We even talked about this in a previous post - Dissecting a versatile Pour Over Recipe

Identifying which is what

Here's how I think about it using flavours we grew up with.

Sour is like biting into raw tamarind before it's sweetened, or raw tamarind leaves. Or that sharp tang from green mango. You feel it on the sides of your tongue, and it makes your mouth pucker.

Bitter is karela. That unmistakable bitter gourd taste that lingers at the back of your tongue. Or strong black tea steeped too long – that dry, chalky feeling.

Once you connect these to coffee, identifying them becomes easier.

Espresso vs Filter

The same principles apply, but intensity differs.

With espresso, everything is concentrated. A sour shot hits sharp and tangy. A bitter one leaves your mouth dry and coated. The 25-30 second window is tight.

With filter, you have more room. Longer extraction spreads things out, making it more forgiving. But the order stays the same – acids first, bitters last.

The Experiment

This is what really helped me understand the difference.

I made a V60 pour over with 15g of coffee ground at around 550 microns, 90°C water, on an 01 size dripper. Used a light roasted natural. The key is to use a separate cup for each pour.

First pour: 50g bloom in cup one. Second pour: 120g in cup two. Third pour: 55g in cup three.

Can you tell which cup has the first pour and which has last?

The results were eye-opening.

Cup one was damn sour. I never thought I would spit coffee, but I did. Pure acidity.

Cup two had a little sourness but lots of sweetness. Great aftertaste. This is what the middle of extraction tastes like.

Cup three was roasty and bitter. That dry, lingering sensation.

Try it once, and you'll never confuse them again.

Quick Fixes

Now that you can identify the problem, here's how to fix it.

If your coffee tastes sour: grind finer, increase water temperature, or extend your brew time. You need more extraction.

If your coffee tastes bitter: grind coarser, lower water temperature, or shorten brew time. You're extracting too much.

We covered this in more detail in the troubleshooting post, but knowing which one you're dealing with is half the battle.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, are you going to try this experiment? Let me know how it goes.

item.title: Brewing Natural vs Washed Coffees
item.description: After months of brewing only naturals, I picked up a bag of washed coffee and completely fumbled the first cup. Turns out, I'd forgotten that these two need different approaches. Here's what I learnt.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I recently bought a bag of washed coffee. It's been so long since I brewed some washed.

All these years, I've been reaching for naturals, the ones that are fruity and jammy, cups that hit different in the morning. But somewhere along the way, I forgot that washed coffees need a slightly different approach.

My first cup with the new bag was underwhelming and hollow. Something was off.

So I went back to research, dug through forums, watched a few videos, and picked up some tips. This is what I learnt.

A Quick Recap on Processing

We talked about coffee processing in a previous post, but here's a refresher.

Washed coffee has the fruit removed before drying. The beans are fermented in water, washed clean of all the mucilage, and then dried. What you get is a cleaner cup with pronounced acidity and a lighter body. You're tasting the bean itself – expect citrus, floral, and sometimes tea-like qualities.

Natural coffee takes a different path. The whole cherry dries intact under the sun for weeks. During this time, the bean absorbs sugars and flavours from the fruit as it ferments. The result is fruity, sweet, full-bodied, and sometimes funky or wine-like.

Naturals in the front and Washed at the back.

Here's the key insight that changed how I brew: naturals are more soluble because of those absorbed sugars. They extract faster and easier. Washed beans are denser and need more convincing.

This is why the same recipe didn't and won't work for both.

Brewing Washed Coffees

With washed coffees, you're chasing clarity and brightness. That clean acidity is the star of the show.

Because these beans are denser, you need to push harder to extract the good stuff.

Grind finer. I go around 16-19 clicks on my Timemore C2. The increased surface area helps water do its job.

Temperature goes up. I brew at 93-96°C. The heat opens up those tight cellular structures and pulls out the delicate flavours.

Tighter ratio. I prefer 1:15 to 1:16 for washed coffees. This concentrates the flavours without making it too intense.

Don't be shy with agitation. More aggressive pours work well here. The cleaner profile means you can push harder without things getting muddy.

Standard bloom of 30-45 seconds is fine.

Brewing Natural Coffees

Naturals are different. The goal here is to balance that fruitiness without overdoing it.

These beans extract so easily that it's surprisingly simple to over-extract them. Go too hard and you'll end up with a boozy, almost fermented funk – and not in a good way.

Grind coarser. Around 21-22 clicks on the Timemore C2. This slows down extraction and keeps the cup light and bright.

Drop the temperature. I stay around 92-95°C. Less heat means a gentler extraction.

Longer ratio. 1:16 to 1:17 works well. The extra water balances out the intensity of those fruit-forward notes.

Go gentle with your pours. Less agitation, slower movements. Let the coffee do its thing without pushing it.

Bloom a bit longer. 40-45 seconds. Naturals trap more CO₂ from all that fermentation, so give them time to degas properly.

Go-To Adjustments

When a natural tastes too syrupy or "winey," the first thing I do is coarsen the grind. That usually fixes it.

If a washed coffee tastes hollow or sour, I bump up the temperature by 2-3°C before touching anything else.

The 4:6 method works beautifully for both – you just adjust your first two pours. For naturals, I put more water in the second pour to tame the acidity. For washed, I go heavier on the first pour to highlight the brightness.

Once I made these adjustments, that washed coffee finally opened up. Bright, clean, with this lovely citrus note I hadn't tasted in months.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, what's your experience? Do you adjust your recipe when switching between naturals and washed? Or do you brew everything the same and let the beans speak?

item.title: Fixing Pour Overs that Clog
item.description: After suffering from stalling brews, these are fixes and techniques I found helpful.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
We've all been there. You're making your morning pour over, everything looks fine, and then the water just... sits there. Refusing to drain.

What should be a 3-minute brew turns into 5, then 6 minutes. By the time it finally drains, you're left with an over-extracted, bitter mess.

Let's talk about why this happens and how to fix it.

Why does clogging happen?

The culprit is almost always fines – those tiny micro particles that come from grinding coffee. They settle at the bottom of your coffee bed and block the filter pores. Entry-level grinders like my Timemore C2 produce more fines than professional grinders. And if you're brewing dense, light roasted beans (the kind grown at high altitudes), they shatter more when hitting the burrs, creating even more fines.

The Obvious Fixes

Grind coarser. This is where I start. Go 2-3 clicks coarser on your grinder and see if it helps. Yes, you might under-extract slightly, but you can compensate.

Increase temperature. Hotter water flows faster and extracts more efficiently. If you went coarser to fix clogging, bump your water temperature by 2-3 degrees to maintain extraction. I sometimes push to 96°C for troublesome light roasts.

Less Pours. When you keep hitting the coffee bed multiple times, the fines sink down and trap the exit. Limiting the pours to 2 or a maximum of 3 should be helpful.

Technique Adjustments

Agitate less. That aggressive stir during bloom? It's pushing fines straight to the filter. Same with pouring too hard or too fast. The turbulence disturbs the bed and sends particles where you don't want them.

Pour gently. Slow, controlled circles. Don't hit the sides of the brewer. Keep the kettle close to the coffee bed. This alone has saved many of my brews.

This video below explains pouring techniques very well.

Advanced Tricks

Water first, then grounds. If you're using a Hario Switch or similar immersion brewer, try adding water first with the valve closed, then gently sprinkling coffee on top. The fines stay floating rather than settling on the filter. Game changer for problematic beans.

Samo Bloom. This one's interesting. Instead of hot water for your bloom, use cooler water around 50-70°C, then continue with your normal temperature. Named after coffee researcher Samo Smrke, the idea is that cooler water doesn't agitate the grounds as much and supposedly preserves more aromatics. Personally, I am not a big fan of this, but it's worth trying.

One more thing – not all filters are equal. Cafec Abaca filters have faster flow rates than standard Hario papers. Switching filters might be the easiest fix of all.

Clogging is frustrating, but once you identify the cause, it's usually simple to fix. Start with grind size, watch your technique, and experiment from there.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, what worked for you when your brew stalled?

item.title: Blending Different Coffee Beans
item.description: An accidental blend of leftover beans led to a surprisingly good cup. Here's what I learned about the art of coffee blending.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I had about 5g of pink bourbon beans left in a bag. Not enough for a full cup. These beans were really sour on their own – the kind of bright acidity that makes you pucker.

Instead of letting them go stale, I threw in 10g of a dark roast I had and made a pour over.

The result was surprisingly good. The dark roast tamed the sourness, while the pink bourbon added a fruity brightness that the dark roast lacked. It was an accidental blend that got me thinking – if random leftovers can work, what happens when you blend with purpose?

Why Blend Coffee?

Roasters have been blending for ages. Here's why it makes sense.

Balance. Every coffee has strengths and weaknesses. One might be too acidic, another too flat. Combine them and you can round off the rough edges.

Consistency. Single origins change with seasons. A blend lets you maintain a taste profile year-round by swapping components as harvests change.

Cost. You can elevate affordable beans by pairing them with premium ones. A solid Brazil as a base with a splash of Ethiopian natural can taste like a much more expensive coffee.

The Building Blocks

Before you start mixing beans randomly, here are the things from my research to consider.

Roast Levels

Similar roast levels blend more harmoniously. Light and dark roasts have different solubility. When you brew them together, one might over-extract while the other under-extracts.

Safe approach is to stay within ranges. Light with medium-light. Medium with medium-dark. You get the idea.

That said, my pink bourbon experiment broke this rule and still worked. So take this as a guideline, not "gospel".

Processing Methods

Washed and natural processed coffees can complement each other beautifully.

Washed coffees provide a clean, bright base. Naturals add fruitiness and body. A classic combination is washed (nutty, chocolatey) with natural (fruity, winey).

Bean Types

Arabica brings complexity, sweetness, and acidity. Robusta adds body, crema, and a caffeine kick.

For filter coffee, most blends stick to 100% Arabica. But for espresso, Robusta plays an important role. More on that follows.

Espresso Blends vs Filter Blends

The brewing method changes everything about how you should blend.

Espresso Blends

Espresso extraction is intense – high pressure, short time. The beans need to withstand this.

Espresso blends are usually roasted darker for better solubility. And here's where Robusta comes in. Italian roasters have been adding 10-30% Robusta to their espresso blends for generations.

Why? Robusta produces more crema. It has higher CO2 content and different fiber structure that creates that thick, golden layer we love on espresso. It also adds body that cuts through milk beautifully. And yes, more caffeine for that morning kick.

Which one could be the blend?

Traditional Italian ratios range from 60/40 to 80/20 Arabica to Robusta. Pure Arabica espresso is delicate and aromatic, but often lacks that substantial crema and body.

Filter Blends

Filter brewing is gentler. Gravity does the work, not pressure.

Here, you want lighter roasts that preserve delicate flavors. Most filter blends are 100% Arabica because you're chasing brightness and complexity, not body and crema.

Origin blends work well – same country, different processing methods. Or same farm, different varietals. The subtle notes have room to shine.

The Indian Classic: Coffee with Chicory

Not all blending involves coffee beans.

South Indian filter coffee traditionally blends coffee with chicory root. This goes back to the French and British colonial times when coffee was scarce and expensive. Chicory, which roasts and brews similarly to coffee, was added to stretch supplies.

The tradition stuck. The classic ratio is 80% coffee (usually Arabica or Peaberry) to 20% chicory.

What does chicory add? Earthiness, woody notes, a fuller body, and slight bitterness. It also cuts the caffeine content – helpful if you're having multiple cups throughout the day.

It's different from specialty coffee blending, but it's a beloved regional twist that millions of South Indians swear by.

Getting Started at Home

Want to try blending? Start simple.

Pick two coffees you already enjoy. Try a 70/30 or 60/40 ratio with one as the base. Brew it. Take notes

Using pre-ground? Just buy two bags you like and experiment with mixing them before brewing. Measure with a scale so you can replicate what works.

The beauty of blending at home is there are no rules. Only your palate.

So {{ first_name | friend }}, have you tried blending your own coffee? What combination would you try first?

item.title: Coffee's Origin and Varietal is a better bet than Flavour Notes
item.description: A story and bit of research on how a recent conversation changed the way I pick my next coffee.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I was at a coffee tasting event last week. We were trying some international beans – Ethiopian, Kenyan, a few Indian ones.

Between sips, I got talking with Aditya from Insanely Good Coffee. He said something that stuck with me.

"Stop chasing flavour notes. Look at the origin and varietal instead. That tells you what to actually expect."

This flipped how I think about buying beans.

The Problem with Flavour Notes

We've talked about tasting notes before. Those "blueberry, dark chocolate, citrus" descriptors on the bag? They're what a cupper perceives while grading. Not a guarantee of what you'll taste.

Cupper can have a different tasting experience. And in the case of international coffees, we might not have tasted half of the notes themselves.

Same beans, different roast, different brew method – completely different notes. Your grinder, your water, your technique – all of these shift what ends up in your cup.

Notes are subjective. Origin and varietal are facts you can build expectations around.

Origin – Where the Coffee Grew

Origin used to be the strongest indicator of how coffee would taste. And while processing methods have blurred some of these lines (a heavily fermented Colombian can taste surprisingly like an Ethiopian now), broad characteristics still hold true.

Ethiopian or Kenyan coffees tend to be fruity, floral, with bright acidity. If you like that tart, citric zing, this is your region.

Brazilian coffees lean chocolatey and nutty. Lower acidity, rounder body.

Let me break down the major regions. India's coffee is unique globally because almost all of it is shade-grown and intercropped with spices – cardamom, pepper, vanilla. This gives Indian beans a character you won't find elsewhere.

Coorg (Kodagu), Karnataka This is often called the coffee cup of India. Karnataka produces around 70% of India's coffee, and Coorg is at the heart of it. Expect chocolatey, nutty cups with medium body and balanced acidity. The spice intercropping sometimes adds a subtle warmth to the finish. Works beautifully with milk or as an everyday filter brew.

Chikmagalur, Karnataka The birthplace of Indian coffee. Baba Budan brought the first coffee seeds here in the 1600s. Expect more complexity than Coorg – berry notes, chocolate, sometimes a spicy kick. The higher altitude here means slower bean development, which translates to brighter acidity and more layered flavours. Great for pour overs.

Baba Budangiri, Karnataka A sub-region within Chikmagalur, but worth mentioning separately. Expect fruity, spicy cups – sometimes wine-like. If you want to taste history, this is where Indian coffee began.

Araku Valley, Andhra Pradesh This is the non-traditional origin. Coffee here is grown by tribal farmers in the Eastern Ghats, often organic. Expect brightness – citrusy, tea-like body, clean finish, mild acidity. This is probably the furthest you'll get from "traditional Indian filter coffee" taste. If you drink black pour overs, Araku is your region.

Nilgiris, Tamil Nadu Higher altitude, cooler nights. Expect bright acidity, floral and fruity aromas, smooth mouthfeel. These beans often taste "cleaner" and lighter-bodied than Karnataka ones. Good for those who want elegance over punch.

Wayanad, Kerala Robusta country. The C x R (Congensis x Robusta) hybrid dominates here – full-bodied, strong aroma, earthy and bold. This is also home to Monsooned Malabar, where beans are exposed to monsoon winds for weeks. The result? Zero acidity, heavy body, earthy and musty character. Perfect for espresso or if you absolutely hate any sourness in your cup.

Koraput, Odisha An emerging specialty region. Clean, fruity flavours with good balance. Worth trying if you want to explore beyond the established origins

Varietal – The Genetics of the Bean

If origin is where the coffee grew, varietal is what the coffee is. Think of it as the DNA.

Now, here's the catch – terroir, processing, and roast level can make it tricky to distinguish varietals. But some stand out clearly.

Gesha is the famous one, and the most hyped. Incredibly floral, citric, delicate. It's difficult to grow and process, which is why it commands insane prices. Not all Gesha is good though – the name alone doesn't guarantee quality.

I drank Sidra before and that's a funky. High on acidity.

For Indian varietals, S795 gives you that classic chocolatey, full-bodied cup. Kent is more elegant – fruity, spicy, sometimes wine-like. SLN 9 (Selection 9) leans bright and complex with citrus notes.

One thing worth noting – Ethiopian coffees often list "heirloom" as the variety. This is a catch-all term for unknown local varietals. It doesn't tell you much, but Ethiopian heirlooms generally deliver floral and fruity profiles.

A Practical Tip

Start keeping notes. Not elaborate ones – just jot down the origin, varietal, and whether you liked it. Over time, patterns emerge. You'll notice you keep enjoying washed Kenyan or natural Rathnagiris.

This changed how I shop for beans now. I scan for origin and varietal first. Flavour notes come later, if at all.

item.title: Americano and Long Black are not same
item.description: These two drinks look and are made almost the same but are different at the core. Let's talk about this often overlooked coffee drink.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I was confidently ordering a "long black", at a cafe in Hyderabad couple of months ago, only to have the barista correct me – "you mean Americano?" I insisted I meant long black. He shrugged and said they're the same thing.

They're not. Or else we would not have them named differently on the menu.

I didn't argue back then and took my Americano, but then I did my research. And found subtle but interesting differences.

Sure, both are espresso diluted with hot water. Both look almost identical in the cup. But ask any Australian barista or Italian coffee purist, and they'll tell you these are two different drinks. It's all about order.

You wouldn’t know the difference by looking at them.

Where They Come From

The Americano has a proper origin story. During World War II, American soldiers stationed in Italy found espresso way too strong for their taste. They were used to the milder drip coffee back home. So Italian baristas did what any good host would do – they diluted the espresso with hot water.

"Caffè Americano" literally translates to "American coffee". Initially, cafes served it with hot water on the side so soldiers could dilute to their preference. Now it's a standard menu item worldwide.

The Long Black, on the other hand, comes from Australia and New Zealand. One unverified theory suggests it was created to appeal to American tourists, though it's equally likely it simply evolved from local coffee preferences. But honestly, it doesn't matter if that's true because Aussies and Kiwis have made this drink their own. In Melbourne or Auckland, ordering a long black is the default for serious coffee drinkers.

The Order Actually Matters

Americano: Pull the espresso shot first into the cup, then pour hot water over it.

Long Black: Pour hot water into the cup first, then gently add the espresso on top.

"Why does this matter?" you might ask.

Crema. That golden layer of coffee oils and microbubbles on top of espresso.

When you pour water over espresso (Americano style), you disturb and break up the crema. It disperses into the drink, giving you a smoother, cleaner body. When you pour espresso over water (Long Black style), the crema stays intact. This preserves more aroma and gives you a richer mouthfeel.

I didn't believe this made a difference until I tasted them side by side. The crema preservation is real.

How They Taste Different

A Long Black hits you with intensity. It's bolder, more concentrated, with the coffee's characteristics front and center. The crema gives you this aromatic start, and the flavor evolves as you drink. It's usually served in smaller cups – around 180-220ml. You're meant to savor it.

An Americano is the gentle cousin. It's milder, smoother, more approachable. The dilution softens the espresso's bitterness while keeping its depth. It's typically served in larger cups (220-350oz), perfect for slow sipping. The taste stays consistent from first sip to last.

Both have the same caffeine content if you're using the same number of espresso shots. The difference is purely in taste and experience.

A third player - Lungo

Lungo stands for "Long" in Italian. While regular espresso extracts for 25-35 seconds, lungos keep going for 45-60 seconds. With a lungo, all the water passes through the coffee grounds during extraction. With an Americano or Long Black, you add water after the espresso is pulled.

I, honestly, don't prefer this, but this is worth a mention. I feel the espresso does a good job of extracting all the good compounds from coffee. And if you keep on extracting, it's just the undesired bitter parts.

Which One Should You Pick?

If you love espresso but find it too intense, go for a Long Black. You get all that bold flavor with the volume turned down just enough. It's still a concentrated experience that lets you taste the beans properly.

If you want something closer to filter coffee (pour over, chemex, aeropress etc) but with espresso's richness, the Americano is your friend. It's less intimidating and easier to drink over a longer period.

Personally? I reach for a Long Black when I'm trying new beans and want to really taste them. Or when I go to a cafe knowing that their coffee tastes best. I go for an Americano when I'm settling in for a long work session and want a bigger cup to sip on.

So which side are you on? Or like the barista I was talking to earlier, do you think I'm overthinking this whole thing?

item.title: Brewing Consistent Pour Overs
item.description: Lessons learnt from years of brewing hit and miss pour over coffee.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
When I started making pour overs, I used to, sometimes, end up with a beautifully tasting cup. But then, I would fail to replicate it.

Next morning, same beans, same everything. Complete disaster.

In this post, I want to share the things that helped me brew consistent pours and even let me replicate a wonderful brew from a week ago.

The Obvious Variables

Grind Size is probably the most impactful variable you control. Once you find your sweet spot, stick to it until taste demands otherwise. Count your clicks religiously. The difference between 19 and 21 clicks is the difference between bright acidity and flat bitterness. Infact, I vary this a lot according to how I like the coffee I brewed last time.

Water Temperature fluctuations matter more than you think. Get a reliable thermometer or temp-controlled kettle. Light roasts need 94-96°C, mediums around 90°C, darks 85-88°C. Yesterday my water hit only 88°C instead of my usual 92°C for a light roast. The cup tasted completely different – not completely bad but it had none of the expected sweetness.

Coffee-to-Water Ratio – use a scale, always. My base is 15g coffee to 250g water (1:16 ratio). Measuring by sight or spoonfuls is just guessing, not brewing.

The Pouring Technique

Channeling is your silent cup-killer. It happens when water finds paths of least resistance through your coffee bed. Some grounds get over-extracted, others barely touched. Result? A cup that tastes both weak and bitter. Weird, right?

Pour in slow circles from center outward, then back. Keep your kettle height consistent – yes this directs how much you agitate the coffee bed. The goal is saturation, not agitation for me. That's because I grind the beans pretty fine. And this could vary for everyone.

More in depth video on the pouring patterns (timestamped) below.

The Often-Overlooked Details

Fresh Coffee – Older beans clump more, might lead to channeling. I order new beans when I have ~120g left so they rest properly by the time I need them. Too fresh coffee is also not good.

Rinse Your Filter – Pre-heating maintains temperature stability. When you pour 94°C water into a cold brewer, you're losing precious degrees. Every degree counts.

Even Coffee Bed – Tap your brewer gently after adding grounds. Mounds and valleys create uneven flow. And even after the last pour, give a small shake or a gentle swirl which will help even out the bed.

Note-Taking Changed Everything

I keep simple notes: "Salawara Estate, 19 clicks, 94°C, still sour" or "21 clicks, 88°C, perfect."

Aravind’s coffee journal

These become gold when you buy the same coffee again. You don't need a fancy journal. Phone notes work fine.

Over time, you start seeing patterns. "Anaerobic naturals work best at 18 clicks." That's when consistency becomes second nature.

Consistency doesn't mean perfection every time. It means when something tastes off, you know exactly what to adjust.

That's the real superpower – not making the perfect cup every single time, but knowing how to get there when you're off track.

So, what's your biggest consistency challenge?

item.title: European Coffee Experience
item.description: I was in Europe last month. This is what I think about Europe's coffee scene.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
I just came back from my trip to Europe.

It was a three-week-long trip covering cities Lisbon, Paris, Milan, Prague and Munich. I wanted to pen down the thoughts and observations about coffee from this trip. So this post will be all about it.

The prep for coffee actually started way before the trip.

I was off coffee and caffeine in general for a week before the trip started. This was because I was drinking way too much coffee and was dependent on it.

I did not want this to be a factor in deciding how good my days are on the trip. And this reset actually helped. I was not craving for it. Sure, I want to try a lot of coffees, but I wasn't dependent.

I did some pre-tip research as soon as my stay was confirmed. I looked for coffee shops and specialty coffee on Google Maps and marked a few places that looked good. I have also spent time on Reddit (r/coffee). This gave me a vague idea of what to expect.

I won’t talk about each city (that would be a long chat. maybe when we meet?) but I will share my core observations.

Espresso still dominates.

People drink it all the time. I don't touch coffee after late afternoon. But I noticed people drink it after a meal, as a breather in between drinks (most surprising), late at night and when not.

You can expect an espresso machine at almost every restaurant and bar.

It felt like espresso is their chai.

Speciality Coffee is rising.

This happens to be the case worldwide, even here in India.

I visited a few speciality coffee cafes as well. And even had a chat with a few baristas there. They say the scene is picking up.

Prague

Munich

Prague

The coffee, I observed, comes mostly from Brazil, Ethiopia, Colombia and Kenya. The price of manual brews (pour over, aeropress, etc.) was 5-8 euros. The espresso is around 3 Euros. A bit higher compared to what we get here.

I bought some beans back home, from shops where they roast their own coffee, Supremo and Man vs Machine. Both roasters are from Munich. The prices for the beans were similar to what we get here.

Supremo Coffee Roasters, Munich

Supremo Coffee Roasters, Munich (yup, same)

The Origin Dishes were good

I tried the coffee desserts that originated in Europe, mainly tiramisu and affogato. They were better.

Umberto 1934, Milan

The affogato is an Italian dessert that literally means “drowned” in Italian, referring to a scoop of ice cream or gelato “drowned” in hot espresso. I tried this in Milan, with gelato and it was top notch. More than the coffee, the quality and taste of the base (gelato) makes or breaks the dish.

Frisca, Milan

Tiramisu was good as well. It is a no-bake dessert made of espresso-soaked breadsticks (savoiardi), layered with a creamy mixture of mascarpone cheese, eggs, sugar, and often flavored with cocoa powder.

Having Tiramisu made with the actual ingredients was interesting to taste. We get this here, but I don't know how many of them use the actual ingredients.

One surprise for me was the fact that Moka Pot originated there as well. I accidentally discovered a Bialetti shop, which I knew has the patent for Mokapot, while strolling around in Milan. Then I realized they are from Italy as well.

I had to pick up this cute Mokapot from there.

I also found that supermarkets across Europe sell ground coffee a lot. And even Nespresso pods were available everywhere. This shows me the scale of household consumption.

Another surprising drink, a cold one, I tried was Club Mate. This is yerba mate (we talked about yerba before), some sweetener, and soda. It was also widely available in supermarkets. This was a nice, refreshing drink with a good caffeine kick.

Overall, I enjoyed Europe's coffee scene. To be frank, I am still enjoying it with the coffee beans I got back from Europe. I’m yet to meet Vikra and give him beans, but I doubt if they will last if he keeps delaying meeting me.

If you have visited Europe, I'd love to know your experience. Or if you plan to visit soon or are getting any beans via friends, we can chat and make a plan.

Have a caffeinated weekend.

item.title: Science of an Espresso
item.description: Let us understand what exactly happens when a barista makes an espresso
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
We will talk about Espresso today, but I have an exciting announcement to make first:

It has been a year since Vikra and I started Caffeinletter. Today is our newsletter's first anniversary.

In the last 12 months, we have grown from zero to 1000 coffee lovers. Thank you for being part of our journey 🤎 

As a gift and celebration, we are launching Baazar today.

You don't need to hop between roasters' websites anymore. Discover all speciality coffees from roasters across India in one place.

You can filter by bean types, roast level, and roasters.

Find your next favourite coffee

So… about Espresso:

We have talked a lot about manual brews. This week, I want to switch gears and tell you a little about what goes on behind a perfect espresso shot.

The way an espresso is extracted is fundamentally different from how a pour-over is made.

Pour-over relies on gravity's 0.1 bar of pressure over 4-6 minutes, whereas, espresso harnesses 9 bars of pressure (roughly equivalent to the water pressure 300 feet underwater) to extract coffee in just 25-30 seconds.

Express-o

9 bars pressure, 95°C temperature, and 25 seconds of extraction time - if not anything, this represents decades of scientific optimisation.

Nine bars create the perfect balance: enough force to emulsify oils and extract compounds that gravity can't touch, but not so much to compress the coffee puck (yes, it's not coffee bed here) into an impermeable wall.

Research demonstrates that pressures above 10.5 bars actually decrease overall extraction due to channeling, while lower pressures fail to create the emulsification necessary for crema.

Temperature operates in a tighter range. At 90°C, you extract acids and sugars efficiently. Push past 96°C, and acids break down into bitter compounds faster than we can blink. Below 90°C? Your sugars stay locked in the coffee matrix while acids dominate.

The barista at your café controls six core variables that interact in complex ways.

  • Dose (typically 18-20g) determines your coffee mass.

  • Yield (36-40g for a 1:2 ratio) controls concentration. The first third of your shot contains 60-65% of total caffeine, while the final third brings mostly bitterness.

  • Grind size exponentially affects surface area; a 10% reduction in particle size can double extraction efficiency.

  • Temperature around 90-96°C.

  • Time (25-30 seconds) - the extraction duration.

  • Pressure - though many machines fix this at 9 bars, pressure profiling machines allow control.

These terms should be enough to strike up a conversation with your barista the next time you visit a café. Trust me, I chat with baristas all the time and they never fail to surprise you.

The Shot

When you pull a shot, here's what happens: The pump creates 9 bars of pressure. Water heated to 93°C enters the group head, where it encounters your tamped coffee puck. In machines with pre-infusion, low-pressure water (2-4 bars) first saturates the grounds for 5-10 seconds, allowing CO2 to escape and preventing channeling. This is like our bloom in pour overs. Then full pressure hits, forcing water through the coffee bed.

It results in a beautiful, bold shot.

Modern machines let you control even the temperature. Just a 1-2°C variation in temperature dramatically affects the coffee extraction as the coffee compound solubility is non-linear.

Espresso demands a radically different approach to grinding than pour-over. Where pour-over uses 600-800 micron particles, espresso requires 200-400 microns, fine enough that halving particle size doubles the surface area exposed to water. This isn't just about going finer, it's about particle distribution.

We need a lot of precision here. Every variable matters because they're all interconnected in ways that make espresso both maddeningly complex and endlessly fascinating. That is also one of the reasons why the machines are costly.

These days I am diving more and more into espressos. Naturally, I will be writing more about them in the coming posts.

If you are a manual brew drinker, I would encourage you to try an espresso next time. Plus actually talk to the barista while he is making it. Appreciating an espresso shot is also a skill, which can be acquired.

We will talk about it someday.

That’s all I have. Have a caffeinated weekend.

See you.

Keep on brewing!

item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
{{ first name |Hey}}, how are you doing? We have a short yet impactful read for you today.

This is a story from a few months ago.

I ran out of coffee beans. While I was waiting for the new order to arrive, I tried exploring quick fixes.

I opened Blinkit and typed in "coffee beans". It led me to Easy Pour packs from Blue Tokai.

"Why not?" was my immediate reaction.

In 15 minutes or so, I was brewing a cup with an Easy Pour packet.

All you have to do is open the filter bag and pour some hot water through it.

Source: Blue Tokai

Coming to the taste, it's not bad at all. Fewer factors to tweak, yes, but it is good for a mediocre cup without any equipment (you only need hot water).

When did specialty coffee become this easy to brew?

Cost per cup amounted to around ₹50, which is higher compared to instant coffee or home brews, but it's worth experimenting because you can gauge if you need to invest in the equipment.

You can find a few options in India:

  • Blue Tokai

  • Toffee Coffee Roasters

  • Beanly Coffee

  • Amazon searches for Easy Pour Coffee

  • Blinkit, Instamart, or any quick commerce

Today’s post is for those who are starting out new (welcome to the club). If you have decided to get the equipment, Fresh Press might be a comfortable first choice.

You can read more about brewing with a French Press here.

Good luck! And write to me about your experience.

item.title: What does honey processed mean?
item.description: Let's look at different processing methods and their impact on your cup of coffee.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
Hello {{ first name | coffee lover }}. What are you brewing this week?

I am travelling across Europe and I can’t wait to share coffee stories with you. Maybe in a couple of weeks, after I am back in Hyderabad.

Understanding the “process” label on coffee bags

I still remember looking at the coffee bags in my initial days of home brewing and wondering what the “honey processed” label meant. I thought the beans were marinated in honey. If nothing else, I expected the cup to have notes of honey.

Soon, I realized that’s not the case. I learnt about how coffee is processed. And it’s quite interesting.

Coffee processing and its effect on the taste

Coffee begins as a cherry-like fruit. Processing is how we get from that fresh fruit to the green beans (which then are roasted to become brown). Think of it like how wine-making transforms grapes into complex wines.

Look at the cross-section picture of the coffee fruit below. This will be a good reference when we talk about the different processing methods, especially the mucilage.

Natural

This is the most obvious and basic way in which the whole coffee fruit is dried. Mucilage and the pulp dry with the seed and latch onto it. This will develop complex flavours and make them sweeter. When these beans with a lot of content on them are roasted, they go through a nice Maillard reaction, which is a standard process in cooking, that results in unique flavours.

Washed

As you might have guessed already, the bean is washed before drying in the washed processing. However, they pick nicely ripe coffee fruits to maintain the sweetness. These are put in de-pulper machines, which leave the beans’ mucilage and remove up to the pulp layer. Then it is water-washed to remove everything else until the seed.

This is generally quicker than the other methods, but a lot of natural resources, like water, are wasted in this method.

These coffees are generally light-bodied and have more brightness.

Honey

Coming to my earlier disappointment, there is no honey involved.

Honey-processed coffee is a method that involves a combination of both the natural and washed methods. You can think of it as the best of both worlds.

They remove the pulp but not the mucilage from the coffee fruit. That mucilage is the honey!

The flavours that these cups give are unique. Cleaner bodies than naturals and more syrupy sweetness than the washed.

Not just these three, but these are the major ones. There is also a fermentation step that people do, which is a topic in itself.

Which one do you think you like?

Despite knowing all the theory and forming a bias for which one you will like, it’s a complete experience in itself, tasting them and figuring out which one you want.

I recommend you try them out and see.

You can go to the cafe and see if they have beans with different processes and order two cups.

Or, there are a few roasters that let you order a sample pack of three different, smaller coffee beans. You can choose different processes to try at home:

  • https://bloomcoffeeroasters.in/products/bcr-custom-sample-pack-of-3

  • https://halflightcoffee.com/products/specialty-coffee-sampler-pack

  • https://kcroasters.com/collections/taster-packs

See you! ☕️👋

item.title: Do you have a favourite cup?
item.description: This is how your cup plays a surprising role in how you perceive your coffee's taste
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
How is it going, {{ first name | coffee lover }}?

If you are a cup hoarder like Vikra (he has 15+ cups), you might have a favourite cup for different coffees, moods, activities, etc.

I have my favourites too. The coffee just tastes better, or a more accurate way of saying this would be drinking from my favourite cups feels wonderful.

I was curious to know why. Not long after, I found myself in another rabbit hole.

Science suggests that the vessel you drink from plays a surprising role in how you perceive your coffee’s taste.

We will talk about it today.

Twitter tweet

Why does coffee taste different in different cups?

Eating or drinking is not the only way your tongue interprets taste. It is a complete sensory experience. Smell, sight, touch, and even our subconscious expectations shape the experience.

The smell makes up for more than half the experience.

We feel we can’t taste food when we catch cold. Wondered why? That’s because our smell is blocked. You can test this for yourself. Close your nose and have food.

Fun Fact: This is also the reason behind using the same cups while cupping coffee (standard protocol to grade coffee worldwide). Imagine not being graded as a specialty coffee because the cupper didn’t like the cup. That would be weird.

What does the research say?

I brewed coffee and poured it into 2 different cups. I was fascinated to observe a heavy black ceramic cup made me feel the coffee was bold and robust. While a light transparent cup tasted brighter. However, both coffees tasted almost identical as I kept sipping. Probably because I knew the coffees were the same and my brain adjusted.

Here are the key differences summarized from the notes I took while researching.

  • Color: White cups tend to amplify the perceived intensity of coffee’s flavor compared to transparent mugs. This might be due to the contrast between the dark coffee and the bright white interior, which primes our brain to expect a more robust taste. Blue and clear cups, on the other hand, often lead to perceiving coffee as smoother and less intense.

  • Shape: The cup’s shape influences more than just how we hold it. Taller, narrower cups tend to concentrate aromatics, enhancing our perception of floral and fruity notes. Wider cups, with their larger surface area, can emphasize chocolate and nutty undertones by allowing more oxygen to interact with the coffee.

  • Touch: The texture and weight of your cup add another layer to the experience. Heavy cups often make us perceive coffee as richer and more substantial, while lighter cups might lead us to focus more on the brighter, acidic notes.

Things to explore

If you are looking to expand your already big collection of coffee cups, I highly recommend the Aroma series of cups that Origami came up with. I bought one myself.

https://brewmethods.com.au/blogs/product-feature/origami-flavour-cups

Here is some more info about such cups.

https://origami-kai.com/en/products/origami-pinotflavorcup

If you have a favourite cup, let me know why it is your favorite and how it makes you feel.

If possible, attach a picture as well. Vikra says he’d love to explore new cups (and probably add 10 more to his collection.)

Have a great weekend!

item.title: How much coffee is too much coffee?
item.description: Let's talk about the science behind and how you can figure it out yourself.
item.dc:creator: Aravind Balla
item.content:encoded:
{{ first name | Hey }}, this will be a long rant about all my research on this topic.

If you Google “How much coffee is too much coffee?” it will give the standard response saying 400mg of caffeine is the FDA-approved limit.

If you make calculations, it will amount to ~4 cups of brewed coffee per day. If you really drink that many cups, it may make you nauseous and jittery.

This is a question I stumble upon a lot. I went down rabbit holes to solve this for myself.

I came to a weird conclusion. It highly varies person to person, and you can guesstimate yours.

Keeping all this in mind, I want to not just talk about what the limits are in general, but also want to leave you with how you can figure this out for yourself and keep enjoying caffeinated drinks for a long time.

Understanding how caffeine works

In simple terms, caffeine blocks the adenosine receptors, the ones that tell your brain it’s time to sleep. It also stimulates the release of chemicals in your brain, which increases alertness. You feel active.

Your Brain On Coffee - YouTube

Over time, your brain thinks you are not resting and increases the number of receptors. That’s the reason you don’t feel the same boost in energy. And also the reason you probably can’t start your morning without caffeine.

This is how our body (mainly the brain) adapts to caffeine.

You will be unstoppable after nappacinno. Try it if you have never done it.

Coming back to caffeine...

Caffeine has a half-life of around 6 hours. This means if you have consumed 100mg of caffeine at 10 am, there is still 50mg of caffeine left in your body by 4 pm. It halves itself every 6 hours.

This is interesting because now we have something to work with.

We all adapt to caffeine.

But anyway, it’s good to know what your limits are.

I have observed that I can sleep well with around 40mg of caffeine, so I try to stay around that. Remember this varies person to person.

50mg seems to be the safe recommended limit. Well, it’s always good to have zero. Because even if we sleep, having caffeine in our system doesn’t let us have a restful sleep. I observed how much sleep I actually needed when I took a week’s break from caffeine—more on that in a second.

If you want to deeply understand what caffeine does to us, this Huberman Lab video is super informative.

How much caffeine is in my coffee

The amount of caffeine that ends up in your cup depends on multiple factors. But we can keep ballpark figures in our mind

Espresso is the easiest. Preparation is standard. One shot has about 75mg.

For every other coffee brewing method, everyone has their own recipes and coffee-to-water ratios. In such cases, we can keep an upper limit. For Arabica coffee, you can get 10mg per 1 gram of ground coffee at max.

So a pour-over brewed with 12g of coffee can have up to 120mg caffeine.

Upper limit is a safe bet. If you want more accuracy, you can read How Much Caffeine in a Coffee Cup? Effects of Processing Operations, Extraction Methods, and Variables paper.

There are also a few apps that promise to calculate amounts of caffeine based on all the parameters. HiCoffee for iPhones is one. It also gives you a graph of residual coffee in your system over time. Really helped me make informed decisions on whether to drink that extra cup or not, which most of the time I ignore, lol.

Before discovering that app, I built a little tracker for myself.

caffeine tracker

What’s your action plan?

Knowing when to stop

Anything in excess is bad. And any addiction is not worth it.

If you have headaches when don’t get your cup of coffee at the time you regularly drink, you are addicted my friend. Try gradually limiting your coffee intake to zero and stay there for at least 2 weeks if you wish to be less dependent on caffeine. Your body will thank you.

The podcast episode from Huberman Lab I shared above talks about different ways to reset.

I took a break from caffeine recently. Not because I was addicted, but mainly because I wasn’t feeling the effects of it after I drank it. I wanted to reset my adenosine receptors. One week is not really enough for them to reset completely but that definitely helped. I immediately felt the difference.
